in a small village nestled among the
hills of ancient Japan a curious scholar
named Hiroshi sought to understand the
Zen concept of the illusory self
determined to grasp this elusive idea he
traveled to a nearby Monastery to meet
with the reverts and master master
Daisuke
upon arriving at the monastery Hiroshi
was led into the garden where Master
Daisuke sat calmly by a tranquil pond
Hiroshi bowed respectfully and asked
Master Daisuke I seek to understand the
Zen teaching of the illusory self can
you help me understand this the master
silently picked up a stone and threw it
into the pond creating ripples that
spread outwards disturbing the
previously calm surface
Master Daisuke then spoke
the stone like our notion of self
disrupts the calm water creating the
illusion of separate entities each
Ripple distinct from the other however
the ripples are merely temporary
disturbances part of the water not
separate from it
so too the self we perceive is like
these ripples in the water of existence
a temporary formation that gives the
illusion of separation from the whole
yet we are not separate entities but
part of the larger reality
water
without the master Rose and walked away
leaving Hiroshi to contemplate the
ripples slowly fading into the calm
Unity of the pond
the word zen comes from the Sanskrit
term Diana which means meditation
Zen Buddhism emphasizes direct
experience and intuitive understanding
rather than relying solely on scripture
or intellectual knowledge
its practitioners seek to awaken to the
true nature of reality through
meditation and mindfulness
Zen teachings often employ paradoxical
language and methods to challenge
conceptual thinking and invite direct
insight into the nature of existence
Zayn made significant inroads into
Western Consciousness in the late 19th
and early 20th century largely due to
the work of DT Suzuki a Japanese author
and translator Suzuki's writings on Zen
Buddhism as well as his translations of
crucial Zen texts had a profound
influence on Western intellectuals and
artists during the mid-20th century
there was an increasing number of Zen
teachers arriving in the west from Japan
and Korea contributing to Zen's spread
by establishing communities and
meditation centers this period also
witnessed a surge of interest in eastern
philosophy and spirituality partly
because of counter-cultural movements
such as the Beat Generation Zen
buddhism's influences can be seen across
many facets of Western culture from
psychology and mindfulness practices to
arts and literature but what is Zen how

both Soto Environ zai Zen are branches
of Zen Buddhism that originated in China
and were later transported to Japan they
share many core principles such as an
emphasis on meditation or zazin and the
achieving of Satori or Enlightenment
though they often interpret the practice
of meditation and Enlightenment in
different ways both schools recommend
direct experience of a theoretical
knowledge value Simplicity and
spontaneity and are closely associated
with mindfulness practices
both schools encourage the practice of
the Arts as expressions of the depth of
one's realization including poetry
martial arts archery pottery and
painting they also share the central
Buddhist teachings of the four noble
truths and the Eightfold Path
one
the truth of suffering dukkha this truth
posits that life as it is typically
lived and experienced is permeated with
suffering
this suffering can manifest in various
forms such as physical pain sadness
dissatisfaction and the inherent
unsatisfactoriness of temporary States
2. the truth of the origin of suffering
samudaya
this truth refers to the cause of
suffering according to Buddhism the
primary cause of suffering is desire or
craving
3. the truth of the cessation of
suffering neroda this truth suggests
that it is possible to end suffering the
cessation of suffering is achieved
through the complete relinquishment of
craving leading to a state of Liberation
known as Nirvana
4. the truth of the path leading to the
cessation of suffering Maga this truth
is essentially the Buddha's prescription
for ending suffering
it is often referred to as the noble
Eightfold Path and consists of right
understanding right thought right speech
right action write livelihood right
effort right mindfulness right
concentration
although rinzai and Sotto are two of the

approaches

puts more focus on seated meditation or

primary means of practice Soto then
focuses on shikantasa or just sitting
shikantasa is a form of objectless
meditation where practitioners are
instructed to be aware of the totality
of their experiences without trying to
manipulate or control them the heart of
shrikantasa is just sitting it is the
practice of fully inhabiting this very
moment this very place just as it is
it is not a means to an end but an end
in itself
as Dogan zenji born at 1200 A.D the
founder of SATA Zen said there is no way
of doing shikanthasa incorrectly just
sit whatever happens is the meditation
Begin by sitting comfortably on a chair
or on a cushion maintain an upright
posture with your spine straight yet not
tense
the chin is slightly tucked in aligning
your head with your spine your eyes
should be half closed softly gazing at a
point on the floor a few feet in front
of you
[Music]
breathe naturally through the nose
let your breath Flow In and Out smoothly
and effortlessly
mindfulness
bring awareness to your posture and
breathing
notice the sensation of breath moving in
and out of your body
notice the feel of your body sitting the
contact of your body with a cushion or
floor
as thoughts arise in your mind do not
attach to them do not engage or suppress
them
simply acknowledge their presence and
let them pass like clouds in the sky

a 20th century zen master shunario
Suzuki was instrumental in popularizing

in Japan he moved to San Francisco in
1959 where he founded the San Francisco
Zen Center his accessible informal
teaching style and his book Zen mind
beginner's mind have had a significant
influence on American Zen practice
he told that one should maintain a
beginner's mind an attitude of openness
and Deaconess in all aspects of life

Cage's most famous piece 4 minutes and

Notions of music by consisting only of 4

The Pianist sits without playing
Cage's artistic approach Guided by Zen
principles revolutionized not only the

boundaries of artistic expression
Alan Watts was a British philosopher
writer and speaker known during the
1960s for his profound insights into Zen
Buddhism and Eastern philosophy Watts
wrote numerous influential books on Zen
including the way of Zen where he
introduced same Concepts to Western
readers blending Eastern wisdom with
Western psychology and philosophy
in his work such as Zen and the best way
and the spirit of Zen Watts explored the
intersections of Zen with modern Western
culture offering fresh perspectives on
spirituality freedom and the Art of
living with his engaging style and
ability to bridge the gap between
eastern and western thought Alan Watts
became an instrumental figure in
introducing Zen philosophy to a wider
audience and inspiring a new generation
of Zen practitioners
the Beat Generation a counter-cultural
literary movement that emerged in the
1950s also played a significant role in
popularizing Zen Buddhism in America
the Beats viewed sin is a means of
Breaking Free from the constraints of
society and exploring alternative modes
of existence
the beads Incorporated Zen ideas into
their writings blending them with their
own experiences and observations on
American culture
the fusion of Zen Buddhism in the beat
lifestyle came to be known as be
Buddhism or beef Zen
Alan Watts reaction to beat Buddhism was
complex he greatly appreciated the
beat's enthusiasm for Zen and their
efforts to incorporate it into their
lives and art
however he also criticized their
tendency to romanticize Zen without
fully understanding its depth and
complexity
Wards believe that true understanding of
Zen required diligent practice and
direct experience rather than simply
adopting an exotic facade
nonetheless Watts recognized the beads
contribution in bringing Zen Buddhism to
the Forefront of Western Consciousness
and sparking interest in eastern
spirituality an interest that continues
in the west to this day
